A Letter from the Director

Dear Visitor, Future Visitor, or Person Who Wandered In Because Our Door Doesn't Latch Properly (Wing B, exhibit #47: "Doors That Don't Close," donated 2014),

Welcome to CATASTROJAZZ 2026, our third annual music festival. I say "third annual" because we held the first one in 2019 and the second one in 2023 and we are choosing not to examine that gap.

For those unfamiliar with the Museum of Perpetual Failure, we are a 501(c)(3) nonprofit institution dedicated to the collection, preservation, and celebration of humanity's most spectacular failures. We opened in 1987 after three prior attempts to open (all documented in our lobby). Our permanent collection spans over 4,200 objects, although that number fluctuates hourly for reasons I will address shortly.

In 1994, I signed a performance contract with a jazz quartet called The Broken Resolutions. Due to language I now describe as "regrettable," that contract has no end date, no break clause, and no definition of a "set." They have been playing continuously in Gallery 3 for thirty-two years. They play in shifts. They sleep in the gift shop. Their bassist, Donovan, has outlived two of the museum's boilers. This festival is our attempt to, as our legal team puts it, "reframe a liability as programming."

Now, about the cats. In 2016, we acquired the complete inventory of Whiskers & Dreams, a cat café that failed after eleven days (it is now exhibit #312). The inventory included 23 cats. They have remained. They knock things off shelves. I want to be honest about this: they knock a lot of things off shelves. Last fiscal year, 340 exhibit items were displaced by feline activity. Our insurance provider has asked us to stop calling them "staff." We have declined.

CATASTROJAZZ is, I believe, the only music festival in the world where the house band cannot be fired, the venue is full of irreplaceable historical artifacts, and two dozen cats are actively working against you. If that sounds chaotic, I'd remind you that chaos is just failure in real time, and failure is what we do best.

Admission is $12. It's $8 if something falls on you. We know what we are.

Dr. Miriam Schuldmann
Executive Director & Chief Failure Officer
PhD, Failure Studies (Gresham Polytechnic, 1983 — closed 1984)

Currently on Display

Status as of this morning. Subject to change. Usually does.

1958

The Ford Nucleon (1:4 Scale Model)

Ford's concept car powered by a small nuclear reactor. Never produced. The model was built by a man who also designed a nuclear-powered toaster (see Wing D, if Wing D is still standing).

● On Display
2003

Nokia N-Gage

The gaming phone you had to hold sideways to make calls. Donated by a Nokia executive who asked to remain anonymous and then signed the donation form with his full name.

● On Floor (Gerald — 3:47 AM Tuesday)
1985

Schuldmann's Left-Handed Scissors

Our founder's first failure: left-handed scissors that were regular scissors turned upside down. 14,000 units manufactured. 14,000 units returned. The remaining inventory is this exhibit.

● On Display (Founder's Collection)
2010

Microsoft Kin Phone

Lasted 48 days on the market. Our shortest-lived exhibit has now outlived the product it commemorates by approximately 5,800 days.

● Shelf Location Unknown (Gerald — twice this week)
1999

Pets.com Sock Puppet (Original)

Authenticated by Sotheby's. Survived the dot-com crash and $300M in losses. Cannot survive Gerald. Currently in protective case since "The Incident of March 2024."

● In Protective Case
2016

Whiskers & Dreams — Complete Cat Café Kit

The failed cat café whose closure gave us our 23 resident cats. Includes: 4 scratching posts, 1 espresso machine (clogged with fur), the original "Grand Opening / Going Out of Business" banner printed on the same day.

● Disassembled by Cats (Ongoing)
1994

The Broken Resolutions' Original Contract

Framed behind glass. Paragraph 7, Clause 3: "The ensemble shall perform for the duration of the engagement." There is no Clause 4. There is no definition of "engagement." Our lawyer at the time has since been disbarred (for unrelated reasons).

● On Display (Legal Wing)
2017

Juicero Press

The $400 juicer whose bags could be squeezed by hand. Donated by a venture capitalist who described it as "the future of produce." We keep it next to a pair of hands.

● On Display

Museum Staff (Feline Division)

23 total. 6 featured below. The others declined to have their photos taken.

Gerald
Chief Disruption Officer
Gerald is responsible for 67% of all exhibit displacement. He shows no remorse. He has been described by our insurance adjuster as "the single greatest liability I have encountered in 30 years of municipal coverage." Gerald weighs 19 lbs.

Gerald arrived in 2016 as part of the Whiskers & Dreams acquisition. Within 72 hours, he had knocked the Betamax display off its shelf, eaten part of the Google Glass exhibit, and somehow opened the locked case containing our New Coke cans. He has been "spoken to" 1,247 times. The conversations have not helped. His favorite target is the Nokia N-Gage, which he has displaced 31 times. We do not know why. He has a personal vendetta against that phone.

Exhibits displaced: 2,891 | Write-ups: 47
Susan
Deputy Director of Napping
Susan sleeps on the Segway exhibit for 18 hours a day. She has never knocked anything off a shelf. We are deeply suspicious of her. No cat is that well-behaved without a motive.

Susan is the only cat who has been formally commended by our insurance provider. Margaret Kowalski (see: Exhibit Damage Assessment, Sunday 11 AM) once described Susan as "the only reason I haven't recommended you shut this place down." We believe Susan is planning something. We have installed a camera on the Segway. The camera has captured 4,380 hours of a cat sleeping. It is the most boring security footage in the history of surveillance. And yet, we watch.

Exhibits displaced: 0 | Suspicion level: EXTREME
Donovan III
Emotional Support (The Broken Resolutions)
Named after both Donovans in the jazz quartet. Sits on the piano during performances. Has become so integrated into the music that audiences assume he's part of the act. He is not. He simply won't move.

First Donovan (bassist, day shift) has grown attached to Donovan III. Second Donovan (bassist, night shift) is allergic to cats. This has not been resolved. Second Donovan plays every set with watering eyes and a box of Benadryl balanced on his amp. Donovan III occasionally steps on piano keys during quiet passages. Audiences have described these contributions as "surprisingly tasteful" and "better than what the pianist was doing."

Piano contributions: 412 | Positive reviews: 6
The Twins (Bankruptcy & Foreclosure)
Co-Directors of Shelf Clearing, Wing B
Identical tabbies who work in tandem. One distracts. One pushes. They have developed a system and we respect it even as we condemn it.

Bankruptcy and Foreclosure (named by our accountant during a difficult fiscal quarter) are responsible for the "Great Cascade of February 2024," in which 14 exhibits fell in sequence over 90 seconds. Security footage shows Bankruptcy making eye contact with a docent while Foreclosure methodically cleared Shelf 7. They have been separated to different wings twice. Both times, they found each other within hours. We have accepted this.

Combined displacement: 743 | Separations attempted: 2
Margaret
Intern (Unpaid)
Named after insurance adjuster Margaret Kowalski, who was not amused. Margaret (the cat) has learned to open the exhibit cases. Margaret (the human) has tripled our premium.

Margaret was the last cat acquired from Whiskers & Dreams. She was 8 weeks old. She is now 10 years old and can open three types of latch. Our security consultant (hired 2021, quit 2022) described her dexterity as "profoundly unsettling for an animal with no thumbs." The protective case around the Pets.com sock puppet was installed specifically because of Margaret. She has been observed studying it.

Cases breached: 17 | Thumbs: 0 (unconfirmed)
Chairman Meow
Gift Shop Attendant
Lives exclusively in the gift shop. Has knocked every magnet off the rack at least once. Visitors assume he is decorative. He is not. He is working.

Chairman Meow generates more revenue than any other staff member, feline or human. Visitors buy magnets, Chairman Meow knocks them to the floor, visitors pick them up feeling a personal connection to the magnet, and purchase rates increase by 23%. We did not plan this. We have nonetheless included it in our fundraising strategy. He has also eaten $140 worth of postcards, which we have written off as "marketing expenses."

Magnets displaced: 4,100+ | Revenue generated: $8,400

"We have asked the Museum to stop calling the cats 'staff' on their insurance forms. They have declined. We have tripled their premium. They have added this to their collection."

Live Incident Log

From CATASTROJAZZ 2023. Published for transparency. Required by insurance.

FRI 12:04
Festival opens. The Broken Resolutions are already mid-song. No one knows when this song started.
FRI 12:11
Gerald knocks the LaserDisc player off Shelf 4. First displacement of the festival. Staff initiate incident report #1.
FRI 12:14
Gerald knocks the LaserDisc player off Shelf 4 again. It had just been re-shelved. Incident report #2.
FRI 1:32
Pamela Deerwood begins her set. The Broken Resolutions do not stop. Two songs play simultaneously. An audience member describes it as "free jazz." First Donovan takes this as a compliment.
FRI 1:38
Gerald walks across Pamela's pedalboard. Entire PA system emits feedback at 4,000 Hz for 11 seconds.
FRI 1:39
Pamela's set paused. Gerald is "relocated." Relocation lasts approximately 4 minutes.
FRI 3:47
Bankruptcy (cat) observed on high shelf in Wing B. Foreclosure (cat) positioned below. Staff recognizes the formation. Shelf cleared preemptively.
FRI 6:02
Dr. Schuldmann performs the Ceremonial Exhibit Drop. Knocks the Theranos miniLab off its pedestal. Clean drop. Audience applauds. Gerald, inspired, knocks the Google Glass off the adjacent shelf.
FRI 6:04
Chain reaction: 7 additional items fall in sequence. Dr. Schuldmann: "This is why we have the festival."
SAT 10:15
The Broken Resolutions have now been playing for 22 consecutive hours. Drummer confirmed alive via pulse check.
SAT 11:30
Dr. Schuldmann begins keynote. Saxophone player increases volume. Dr. Schuldmann increases volume. This continues for 45 minutes.
SAT 1:00
Gerald feeding time. All guests move to center of room. Three items fall during the transition. One was already on the floor.
SAT 3:12
Trombone Betty & The Near Misses begin performing alongside The Broken Resolutions. Combined sound levels reach 94 dB. Margaret (cat) opens the Zune exhibit case during the noise. No one notices.
SAT 5:30
Silent auction begins. It is not silent. Nothing in this building is silent. The Broken Resolutions play.
SAT 9:14
Pamela Deerwood joins The Broken Resolutions on stage. Begins improvising lyrics about her experience at the festival. Audience moved to tears. Donovan III walks across piano. Standing ovation.
SUN 9:00
Hour 69. Second Donovan weeping openly while playing. States it is "the Benadryl." No one believes him.
SUN 11:00
Margaret Kowalski (insurance) arrives. Gerald immediately knocks the Segway exhibit guide off the desk. Susan does not move from the Segway itself. Margaret Kowalski (cat) opens a display case in what we can only describe as a power move.
SUN 2:00
Re-shelving ceremony begins. 47 items need to be replaced. Gerald placed in carrier. Gerald escapes carrier in under 90 seconds. This is a new record.
SUN 4:00
The Broken Resolutions announce their "closing set." They said this in 2019. We will see.
SUN 11:59
Festival officially over. The Broken Resolutions are still playing. Gerald is asleep on the Nokia N-Gage. Total incident reports filed: 142. Total exhibits displaced: 89. Total cats spoken to: 23. Outlook for 2026: optimistic (Dr. Schuldmann), "deeply concerning" (Margaret Kowalski).

Frequently Asked Questions

No. We have consulted four law firms, two mediators, and a priest. The contract signed on March 14, 1994 contains the phrase "for the duration of the engagement" with no termination clause, no sunset provision, and no definition of "engagement." Our most recent legal counsel described the document as "a masterpiece of accidental permanence." The Broken Resolutions are aware of their power. They have negotiated three raises since 2010.
23. We acquired 23 from Whiskers & Dreams in 2016 and we maintain 23 today. We have never gained or lost a cat. This is the single most successful operation in the museum's history and we find it deeply suspicious.
Gerald is not dangerous to humans. Gerald is dangerous to objects on shelves, objects on desks, objects on pedestals, objects in cases (if the case is open or if Margaret has opened it), musical equipment, insurance premiums, and the concept of institutional order. He weighs 19 pounds and is not sorry. Our veterinarian has described him as "clinically indifferent to consequence."
Yes. Our premium is $47,200/year, which is roughly 11x the average for a museum of our size. Our policy contains a clause our provider refers to as "the Gerald Addendum," which specifically addresses "damage caused by resident felines in excess of normal feline activity." We have asked what constitutes "normal feline activity" and have not received a satisfying answer. We have added the unanswered email chain to our collection (Wing C, Shelf 12, "Failures of Communication").
We tried this. Margaret (cat) can open three types of latch. Gerald can push a 5-pound glass case off a shelf. Bankruptcy and Foreclosure, working in tandem, can displace a case and its contents in under 30 seconds. The cases themselves became exhibits (Wing A, "Failures of Containment"). We have accepted that our collection is, in a very real sense, participatory.
Email submissions@museumofperpetualfailure.org with a description of your failure, supporting documentation, and a brief statement on why your failure deserves preservation. We accept objects, documents, screenshots, prototypes, and business plans. We do not accept food (anymore — see exhibit #208, "The Sourdough Incident of 2020"). Current backlog: 14 months. Gerald cannot read your application but will interact with it once it is on display.
We don't know. It has not happened. The closest we came was the power outage of 2017, during which the drummer played in complete darkness for four hours. He later described this as "some of my best work." Structurally, the museum has been vibrating at a low frequency for 32 years. Our facilities team has advised us that the building may have "acoustically adapted" to continuous jazz. What that means for a sudden silence is, frankly, unknown, and we are not eager to find out.
